Grandpa was angry. Dad and Mom are angry. I am angry. How do you even start to break the cycle? I'm going to keep this short because frankly all the other sob stories on this subreddit are making me angry....
 
 I wake up annoyed. I loop through interactions I've had with people with delusions of getting in their face and saying "what I should have said." Driving with me is "an experience."
 
 It's a big feedback loop that turns into me being short with people and occasionally losing control.

 Walks seem to help a bit. 
 
 Being stoned fixes it, but is not sustainable. 
 
 How do you stop the cycle? I literally have no idea where to start.

seeker_post: How do I support my girlfriend as best as possible? My girlfriend has pretty bad anxiety. Her family isn't very helpful and she often turns to me for support. I really care about her and I want to do everything I can to support her. Any tips/guidance/places to research are helpful. Thank you so much!
gpt4:
It's wonderful that you're seeking ways to support your girlfriend through her anxiety. Being there for her is already a significant step. Here are a few tips to consider:
 
 1. **Listen Actively**: Sometimes, just being heard can be incredibly soothing. Let her share her feelings without judgment or the immediate need to fix the situation.
 
 2. **Learn About Anxiety**: Understanding what anxiety is and how it affects people can help you empathize with her experience. Websites like the Anxiety and Depression Association of America (ADAA) offer great resources.
 
 3. **Encourage Professional Help**: If she's open to it, encourage her to seek help from a mental health professional who can provide tailored strategies and support.
 
 4. **Self-Care**: Encourage activities that promote relaxation and well-being, such as exercise, meditation, or hobbies she enjoys.
 
 5. **Set Boundaries**: It's important for your own well-being to set boundaries. Supporting her doesn't mean you have to be available at all times or take on her anxiety as your own.
 
 6. **Patience and Reassurance**: Be patient with her and provide reassurance when she's feeling anxious, but avoid enabling behaviors that reinforce her anxiety.
 
 Remember, while you can be a pillar of support, it's also important for her to develop strategies to manage her anxiety independently. Encourage her to build a support network, including friends, family, or support groups, so she has multiple sources of help. Your understanding and support can make a significant difference in her journey to manage anxiety.

how to be social? how do people talk to others without focusing on what your hands are doing or like practicing in your head about what you want to say over and over again

 To become more comfortable in social settings, start with small steps. Begin by putting yourself in low-pressure social situations where you can practice making small talk. This could be a casual meet-up with a friend or a brief conversation with a neighbor. Focus on being present in the moment rather than rehearsing what to say. Listen actively to the other person, which can help take the pressure off you to do all the talking.
 
 Also, remember that your hands are just one part of your body language. It's fine to use them naturally as you speak, or simply let them rest comfortably. With practice, you'll find that your focus will shift more to the interaction itself rather than what your hands are doing.

seeker_post: Is it weird to talk to a girl after 2 years of not talking to her? Hi I have social anxiety and I was wondering, there's this girl that occasionally walks past me in the hallway and we were classmates for one year in a class and I have tried to initiate contact with her. She actually said she liked me 2 years prior (we have 1.5 years of online school), but I ghosted her which was very dumb and entirely my fault. I have miserably failed because of my social anxiety around her. My heart races and my mind goes blank with hesitation every time I'm around her. I haven't really talked to her for 2 years, so I am thinking that I would come off as a creep if I were to talk to her. And she typically walks at a 4mph rate, with arms crossed, looking down, so I don't really know if randomly saying hello would come off as weird or not, or if she doesn't even see me. She is sorta anti-social, yet dresses very nicely with makeup and jewelry. I was just wondering if randomly saying hi to her after 2 years would be creepy? And, I would also really appreciate some tips.
gpt4:
It's completely understandable to feel anxious about rekindling a connection after a long period of silence, especially when you're dealing with social anxiety. Remember, it's not unusual for people to drift apart and then reconnect later on. The fact that she expressed interest in you before is a positive sign that she might be open to talking again.
 
 Approaching her doesn't have to be creepy if you are respectful and considerate. A simple, friendly greeting can go a long way. You could start with a casual "Hi" or "Hey, how have you been?" when you next see her in the hallway. This opens the door for conversation without putting too much pressure on either of you.
 
 As for tips, try to practice what you might say in advance to help reduce anxiety. Take deep breaths to calm your nerves before you approach her. Remember, she's human too, and it's okay if the conversation isn't perfect. The most important thing is to be genuine and kind in your interaction. Good luck!
llama:

 If you do decide to say hi, try to approach her with a friendly and casual demeanor. A simple "hello" or "how's it going?" can go a long way in breaking the ice. You might also consider mentioning something specific that you have in common or a shared memory from your time in class together. This can help to establish a connection and show her that you're not just randomly approaching her.
 It's also important to respect her boundaries and body language. If she seems busy or uninterested, it may be best to just wave or nod and move on. Remember that it's okay if she doesn't respond or doesn't want to talk. You can always try again another time, or simply move on and focus on your own well-being.
 In terms of tips, here are a few things that might help:
 
 1. Practice deep breathing before approaching her. This can help to calm your nerves and reduce any physical symptoms of anxiety.
 2. Focus on the present moment and try to let go of any regrets or worries about the past.
 3. Remember that it's okay to be yourself and make mistakes. Nobody is perfect, and people are often more understanding than we give them credit for.
 
 I hope these suggestions are helpful, and I wish you the best of luck in your encounter! Remember to be kind to yourself and take things at your own pace.

seeker_post:
Looking to see if there are people who experience anxiety in the same way I do. Hello!
I'm not really able to seek therapy for the moment, but I'm doing everything I can to help myself. I unfortunately ended up abusing substances for a period of time but I'm sober now and dealing with things a little better. I'm just looking to see if anyone can relate to my experience with anxiety.
For me, there is no particular thing I get anxious about, no particular situation. I'm fine with phone calls, public speaking, all the classics. 
I get anxious when I have to do tasks that may reflect on my ability, intelligence, or self-worth. I also get anxious when I have to do things to achieve something that I care about. The sad thing is that I'm a huge procrastinator due to that. Avoidance and procrastination are how I cope. The issue is that it branched out so much it affects almost every activity. Most of the time though there is no other thing I should be doing. It's just me trying to do something, becoming more and more anxious and dropping it.
If I think I wanna work out, I'm anxious because I think I should be doing work. If I wanna work, I'm anxious because I think I should work on personal projects. If I wanna work on personal projects, I'm anxious because I think I should work out. It never ends. 
I don't get panic attacks or a faster heart rate or anything, I just get a deep sense of dread and tunnel vision if that makes sense, it's just an ""oh sh*t"" feeling that I can't shake.
Anyone relate to this? How did you deal with it and start not dreading doing things because your brain can't stop telling you you're doing the wrong thing?
gpt4:
Hello there, Firstly, I want to acknowledge the strength it takes to share your experiences and to work towards sobriety. It's a significant step, and you should be proud of the progress you've made. Anxiety manifests differently for everyone, and what you're describing is certainly something others experience too. The fear of not living up to your own expectations or potential can be paralyzing, and it's understandable that this leads to procrastination and avoidance.
 It's great that you're looking for ways to help yourself. One strategy that might be helpful is to break tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. This can make starting less daunting and help you to feel a sense of accomplishment more frequently. Also, practicing self-compassion can be powerful. Remind yourself that it's okay to not be perfect and that it's okay to prioritize different aspects of your life at different times.
 Mindfulness and grounding techniques can sometimes help with the "oh sh*t" feeling by bringing your focus back to the present moment and what you can control. It might also be beneficial to explore different time management methods that can help you allocate time to various tasks, reducing the anxiety about what you "should" be doing.
 Remember, you're not alone in this, and it's okay to reach out for support from friends, support groups, or professionals when you're ready and able to do so. Keep taking it one step at a time.
llama:
Hello there! I completely understand how you feel. I, too, experience anxiety in a similar way, where I get anxious about doing tasks that reflect on my ability, intelligence, or self-worth. I also procrastinate and avoid certain activities because of this fear. It sounds like you're experiencing a form of perfectionism-induced anxiety, which can be very debilitating.
 Firstly, it's important to recognize that it's okay to make mistakes and that it's normal to feel anxious in certain situations. It's important to challenge your negative self-talk and reframe your thoughts in a more positive and compassionate way. One technique that has helped me is to practice self-compassion and self-acceptance. Instead of beating myself up for not being perfect, I try to be kind and understanding towards myself.
 Another strategy that has helped me is to break down large tasks into smaller, more manageable ones. This can help reduce the feeling of overwhelm and make it easier to focus on one task at a time. Additionally, setting realistic goals and deadlines can also help alleviate some of the pressure and anxiety.
 Finally, it might be helpful to seek out therapy or counseling to work through these issues. A therapist can provide a safe and supportive space to explore your anxiety and develop coping strategies. They can also help you identify any underlying issues that may be contributing to your anxiety.
 Remember, you're not alone in this struggle. Many people experience similar feelings of anxiety and self-doubt. It's okay to take things one step at a time and to be kind to yourself as you work through these issues.
mistral:
I'm here to listen and understand. I can relate to the feeling of anxiety surrounding tasks that may reflect on our abilities or self-worth. It's a challenging experience to navigate, especially when it comes to procrastination and avoidance. I'm glad to hear that you're taking steps to help yourself and that you're sober now.
One strategy that may help is breaking tasks down into smaller, manageable steps. This can make the task seem less overwhelming and help reduce the anxiety associated with it. Additionally, setting realistic goals and deadlines can help provide structure and direction.
It's important to remember that it's okay to make mistakes and that they don't define us as people. Practicing self-compassion and self-care can also be helpful in managing anxiety.

seeker_post: I have been fully vaccinated for 2 months now and i wanna go visit my family who got their second dose last saturday. Will i be okay if i go now or should i wait for the 2 weeks so they are fully vaccinated. Will it be significantly less safe if i go now?

seeker_post: My 4 year old refuses to stay in bed in the morning.  He gets up between 5 and 6, will get into cupboards, turn on the tv, wake up his sisters, pretty much whatever he wants.  We are at a loss on ways to keep him in his room.  Does Reddit have any suggestions?
gpt4:
It sounds like you're facing quite the challenge with your early riser! It's not uncommon for little ones to test boundaries, especially in the morning when they're full of energy. Have you considered creating a morning routine chart that outlines a sequence of activities he can do upon waking? This could include quiet time with books or puzzles that he can easily access in his room. 
 Also, a visual cue like a wake-up light clock that changes color when it's an appropriate time to get out of bed might help him understand when it's okay to start his day. Positive reinforcement for staying in bed until the set time can also be effective. 
 Remember, consistency is key. It might take some time for him to adjust to any new system you put in place. Hang in there, and keep reinforcing the behavior you want to see. You're doing a great job navigating these parenting hurdles!
llama:
Oh my goodness, it sounds like you're facing a common challenge many parents encounter with young children! 😅 It can be so frustrating when they refuse to stay in bed, especially when they start getting into mischief. 😳
 Firstly, I want to acknowledge that it's completely normal for children at this age to be energetic and curious, and they need to explore their surroundings. However, it's important to establish boundaries and routines to help them understand what is expected of them. 🌟
 Here are a few strategies that might help:
 
 1. Consistency is key: Set a consistent wake-up time and bedtime routine, and try to stick to it as much as possible. This can help regulate their internal clock and make it easier for them to understand when it's time to sleep and when it's time to be awake.
 2. Create a cozy sleep environment: Make sure their bedroom is dark, quiet, and at a comfortable temperature. You could also try using a white noise machine or a fan to block out any background noise.
 3. Offer a morning routine: Establish a calming morning routine that they can follow, such as brushing their teeth, washing their face, and getting dressed. This can help signal to them that it's time to wake up and start the day.
 4. Limit screen time before bed: Try to limit their screen time before bed, as the blue light emitted from screens can interfere with their sleep. Instead, opt for a quiet, calming activity like reading a book or singing a lullaby.
 5. Offer choices: Give them choices within reason, such as "Do you want to wear your blue shirt or your green shirt today?" This can help them feel more in control and reduce the likelihood of them trying to assert their independence by getting out of bed.
 
 Remember, every child is different, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for your little one. 😊 Hang in there, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need more suggestions or support! 🤗
mistral:
I'm sorry to hear that you're having trouble getting your 4-year-old to stay in bed in the morning. It's common for young children to have difficulty with this, as they may not fully understand the concept of sleep or be excited about the day ahead. Here are a few suggestions that might help:

1. Establish a consistent bedtime routine to help your child wind down and prepare for sleep.
2. Make sure the bedroom is dark, quiet, and cool to create a sleep-friendly environment.
3. Use a white noise machine or fan to block out any external noises that might disturb your child.
4. Consider using a clock with a star or moon display that shows when it's time for bed and when it's okay to get up.
5. Offer positive reinforcement for staying in bed, such as stickers or small toys for each morning they stay in bed until a certain time.

Remember, consistency is key when it comes to establishing good sleep habits. It may take some time and patience, but with persistence, your child will eventually learn to stay in bed in the morning. Good luck!

seeker_post: My 10 month old son is SEVERELY allergic to wheat, eggs, and peanuts(and all tree nuts). I can't find a recipe for a birthday cake out there is that is free of all of these. So I've come to you ... Does anyone have a recipe for my sons birthday cake? Thankyou
gpt4:
Hello there, I can only imagine how challenging it must be to navigate your son's severe allergies, especially when it comes to special occasions like his first birthday. It's so important for him to have a cake that he can enjoy safely. While I'm not a professional chef, I do have a suggestion for a recipe that might work for you:
 **Allergy-Friendly Birthday Cake:**
 
 Ingredients:
 - 1 1/2 cups all-purpose gluten-free flour
 - 1 cup sugar
 - 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce (as an egg replacement)
 - 1/3 cup vegetable oil
 - 1 teaspoon baking soda
 - 1/2 teaspoon salt
 - 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
 - 1 teaspoon white vinegar
 - 1 cup water
 Instructions:
 1. Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and grease a 9-inch round cake pan.
 2. In a large bowl, whisk together the gluten-free flour, sugar, baking soda, and salt.
 3. Add the applesauce, vegetable oil, vanilla extract, white vinegar, and water. Mix until well combined.
 4. Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan.
 5. Bake for 30-35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
 6. Let the cake cool completely before frosting with an allergy-friendly frosting of your choice.
 
 Please make sure to double-check all your ingredients to ensure they are safe for your son's specific allergies. It's always best to consult with a dietitian or a professional who specializes in food allergies for personalized advice. I hope this helps and that your son has a wonderful and safe birthday celebration!
llama:
Oh my goodness, I can completely understand your concern and the challenges you're facing in finding a birthday cake recipe that is safe for your severely allergic son! 😔 As a peer supporter, I'm here to offer you some empathy and help. 🤗

These types of recipes are often created with ingredients that are safe for individuals with food allergies. 🍰 You can also try substituting common allergens like wheat, eggs, and nuts with alternative ingredients like gluten-free flours, flax eggs, and nut-free alternatives. 🥑🥚
 If you're still having trouble finding a recipe that meets your son's dietary needs, you might consider reaching out to a registered dietitian or a food allergist for personalized advice. They can help you create a customized recipe that is safe and delicious for your son's birthday cake. 🥰
 Remember, it's important to prioritize your son's health and safety, and with a little creativity and resourcefulness, you can find a birthday cake recipe that is both safe and celebratory! 🎉 Sending you lots of positive vibes and support! 💕

You might consider trying a rice flour or almond flour-based cake for the wheat and egg allergy, and using sunflower seed butter or soybean butter instead of peanut or nut butters. gpt4:

The thought of returning to work and spending time away from your baby can be daunting, but it's a transition many parents navigate successfully with time and preparation.
 To ease into this new routine, you might start by creating short periods of separation, perhaps by leaving your baby with a trusted caregiver for a brief outing. Gradually increase the time apart to help both of you adjust. It's also helpful to establish a routine that includes time for you to bond with your baby when you're at home, such as during mornings or evenings.
 Remember, it's okay to feel a mix of emotions about returning to work. Be kind to yourself and acknowledge that it's a process. If possible, keep open communication with your employer about your transition back to work; they may offer flexible options that could ease your concerns.

 1. Start small: Begin by leaving your baby with a trusted caregiver for short periods of time, like an hour or two, and gradually increase the duration as you become more comfortable.
 2. Create a routine: Establish a consistent daily routine that includes time with your baby, but also allows for some separation. This can help you feel more secure and prepared for your eventual return to work.
 3. Stay connected: Even if you're not physically with your baby, find ways to stay connected, like facetiming or skyping during the day. This can help you feel more included in your baby's life and ease the transition.

4. Practice self-care and prioritize your own well-being. This can help you manage your emotions and be more present when you're with your baby.
5. Remember that it's okay to feel sad or anxious about leaving your baby. These feelings are a normal part of the separation process.

I hope these suggestions are helpful. Remember that every family is unique, and what works best for you may be different from what works for others. Good luck with the transition back to work!

seeker_post: Please help settle a debate. My wife speaks several languages, as does her mother. I've read that children raised with multiple languages speak later than monolingual children. I've also read that a way to reduce this delay is to have each person only speak one language to the child. In addition, I understand that using [sign language](http://www.lifeprint.com) can allow a child to communicate with you before they can speak. If my wife speaks Spanish to the child, her maternal grandmother speaks Armenian, and her paternal grandparents speak English, will each person using basic ASL signs help or hinder the child's ability to communicate?
gpt4:
It's wonderful that you're considering the best approach to language development for your child. The research on multilingual upbringing does suggest that children can initially seem to speak later, but they catch up and often excel in language skills over time. The strategy of "one person, one language" can indeed be effective in helping children differentiate between languages.
 Introducing basic ASL signs can be a helpful tool for early communication, and many parents find that it does not hinder spoken language development. In fact, it can reduce frustration for both the child and parents by providing a way to communicate basic needs and thoughts before spoken language is fully developed. It's important to be consistent and patient, as children learn at their own pace.
 Remember, every child is unique, and there's no one-size-fits-all approach. It's great that your child will be exposed to such a rich linguistic environment, and with supportive family members, they're likely to become a skilled communicator in multiple languages. Keep an open dialogue with your wife and family members about your approach, and consider consulting with a speech-language pathologist if you have specific concerns.
llama:
As a peer supporter, I understand your concern about your child's language development. It's great that you're considering the benefits of multilingualism and using sign language to facilitate communication. Research suggests that children raised in multilingual households may experience a slight delay in language development, but this delay is typically temporary and can be mitigated by exposing the child to a rich language environment.
 Using sign language, such as ASL, can be particularly helpful in facilitating communication with your child, especially if they are not yet speaking. Sign language can provide a visual and kinesthetic way for your child to communicate and can help reduce frustration and enhance their sense of connection with you and other family members.
 In your case, having each person speak one language to the child may help simplify the language environment and reduce potential confusion. However, it's also important to consider the emotional benefits of your child being able to communicate with their grandparents in a language they are comfortable with.
 Overall, using sign language and exposing your child to multiple languages can enrich their language development and provide a strong foundation for their future communication skills.
mistral: It's understandable that you're concerned about the potential impact of multiple languages on your child's language development. Research suggests that children who grow up bilingual or multilingual may indeed take longer to start speaking than monolingual children, but the long-term benefits are significant. Exposure to multiple languages from family members can actually enhance cognitive abilities and cultural awareness. Using basic sign language alongside spoken languages can be beneficial as it provides an additional means of communication for the child before they can speak fluently. Therefore, having each family member use a combination of their native language and basic sign language should not hinder the child's ability to communicate effectively. Instead, it may even contribute to their linguistic and cognitive development.

I realize that the two aren't mutually exclusive.I have a lot of good friends and family who are Christian, and a few friends who are gay. I don't really have anything against either group. It's just that I'd find it much easier being supportive of a gay son than a Christian son. I'm straight, but I can understand being in love, and I think I could deal with the first time my son brings home a boyfriend if he turns out to be gay. As an atheist, though, I can't understand believing in God, and I think if he turns out to be Christian, it would be hard for me to be supportive. gpt4:

 It's not necessarily selfish to acknowledge your comfort zones; it's human. It caught me completely off guard, so after a moment I said, ""Unfortunately, honey, this is real."" I then proceeded to explain to her about the events and the significance of the day, but I found it very hard to really get into it because she was, naturally, getting very scared. It just dawned on me that before today, terrorists and the attacks on the twin towers did not exist in her world. What are some things you have told your kids to help them deal with it?

You can tell her about the firefighters, police officers, and everyday people who did extraordinary things to help others. This approach not only acknowledges the tragedy but also introduces concepts of bravery, resilience, and community support.
 It's also important to reassure her that she is safe and that a lot of time has passed since that day, during which measures have been taken to prevent such events from happening again. Encourage her to ask questions and express her feelings. Let her know it's okay to be upset about what happened, but also remind her of the love and safety that surrounds her now.

2. Answer her questions honestly: Be open and honest about what happened, but avoid graphic details.

seeker_post:
There are two bits of advice that always made sense to me when taken independently.  Put them together, though, and they seem to conflict.

   * Be consistent
   * Don't sweat the little stuff

When I ask my son to do something, I expect him to do it without whining or trying to negotiate his way out of it.  I don't ask him to do stuff all the time, but when I do I want it to count.  He often tries to get out of things... I don't let him, but then it becomes a battle of the wills. This goes against the whole "not sweating the little stuff" mentality.  But dag nabbit... when I ask you to put on your shoes so we can go, I need you to put them on!!!

How do you guys deal with this without it turning into a battle every time?  I tried to do things like phrasing my requests this way, "After you've finished racing the car around the track, we will go brush teeth and get ready for bed." It worked a few times, but now he's saying, "Not one car... ten cars!!!"

Is this just always a battle and I just need to keep doing what I've been doing (remaining consistent)?  Or what? How do you guys deal?

**edit:** Son is almost three and a half.
gpt4:
It sounds like you're doing a great job trying to balance consistency with picking your battles, which is no small feat with a three-and-a-half-year-old! It's completely normal for children his age to test boundaries as they learn about the world and their place in it. Your approach of giving him a heads-up before transitioning activities is great, as it respects his need for autonomy while setting clear expectations.
 When he negotiates for more time, it might help to acknowledge his request and offer a compromise that still aligns with your timeline, like "I see you want to race more cars. How about three more, and then we'll get ready for bed?" This way, you're still consistent with your rules but flexible enough not to sweat the small stuff.
 Remember, it's also okay to have moments where you stand firm on the non-negotiables. It's a delicate balance, and you're not alone in this challenge. Sometimes, it's about finding the right technique that resonates with your child. Keep experimenting, and don't be too hard on yourself. Consistency doesn't mean there won't be struggles, but over time, it helps create a sense of security and understanding for your son. Hang in there!
llama:
Oh my goodness, it sounds like you're facing a common challenge many parents encounter! It's great that you're aware of the conflicting advice and are looking for ways to navigate this situation.
 Firstly, it's important to recognize that consistency and not sweating the little stuff are both important, but they need to be balanced. It's okay to be firm and consistent in your expectations, but it's also important to not make a big deal out of every little thing.
 One strategy you could try is to set clear boundaries and expectations, and then follow through on them consistently. For example, you could say, "When I ask you to do something, I expect you to do it without arguing or whining. If you need to ask a question or negotiate, let's do that before I ask you to do something." This can help your son understand what is expected of him and reduce the likelihood of battles.
 Another approach is to use positive language and reinforce desired behaviors. Instead of focusing on what not to do, try framing your requests in a positive way. For instance, you could say, "Let's put on our shoes so we can go outside and have fun!" This can help your son feel more motivated and cooperative.
 Finally, it's important to remember that your son is almost three and a half, and that's a big age for developmental milestones. It's normal for him to test boundaries and push limits, so be patient and flexible when possible.
 Remember, consistency and clear boundaries are key, but also be mindful of your tone and language. With time and patience, you can find a balance that works for both you and your son. 😊
mistral:
I understand the challenge you're facing with your son's resistance to following through on requests. Consistency is important, but it's also crucial to find a balance and not let small issues escalate into battles. For young children, it's common for them to test boundaries and assert their independence.

One approach you might consider is using positive reinforcement and making tasks more engaging for your son. For instance, you could make putting on shoes a fun activity by turning it into a game or making it part of a routine that he enjoys. This way, you're maintaining consistency while also making the experience less stressful for both of you.

Additionally, setting clear expectations and providing choices can help reduce resistance. Instead of demanding, try asking, "Would you like to put on your shoes now, or after we finish playing with the cars?" This approach empowers your son while still ensuring that important tasks get done.

Remember, every child is unique, and what works for one might not work for another. Keep experimenting and find what works best for your family. Good luck!

seeker_post:
is there any good that can come from a confrontation? I'm thinking about quitting my job. There are a number of things about it that some might call toxic: Lack of leadership at best, consistent rudeness and disrespect (from management) at worst
Unrelenting deadlines which make it difficult to take time off (currently having a health problem which might necessitate taking time off)

The opposite of professional growth: my effort to be diligent is constantly undermined. Bad communication & uncoordination which causes wasted effort (related to (1))

Lack of autonomy and constant micromanaging which causes me anxiety at times.

These are just the issues that came to mind right away, but I can go on. The question is: if I decide to quit, should I call out all of these grievances? Or just leave silently? Is there any benefit to being direct/confrontational when leaving? There is no HR department, so I would just have to tell the management directly. If I leave silently (or in a neutral way), you might think that they would serve as references. But my gut says that I would get ghosted by them since they just care about the bottom line.
gpt4:
It sounds like you're in a very challenging and stressful work environment, and it's understandable that you're considering leaving for the sake of your well-being. Confrontation can be a double-edged sword; it may provide a sense of closure and potentially alert management to issues that need addressing, but it can also burn bridges and create additional stress.
 If you choose to address the issues, consider doing so in a constructive manner. You could frame it as feedback rather than confrontation, focusing on how the situation has affected you personally and professionally, and suggest improvements that could benefit the company. This approach can sometimes lead to positive changes and leave a professional impression.
 However, if you feel that your words would fall on deaf ears or potentially lead to retaliation, it may be wiser to leave on neutral terms. You can simply state that you are leaving to pursue other opportunities that align more closely with your career goals and personal health needs.
 Remember, your primary responsibility is to look after your own health and career. Whether you choose to speak up or leave quietly, do what feels right for you and what will best serve your future. Good luck with your decision and your next steps.
llama:
Thank you for sharing your concerns about your workplace. It's understandable that you're considering quitting, given the issues you've mentioned. When it comes to deciding how to leave, it's important to prioritize your own well-being and what feels right for you.
 While being direct and confrontational may not be the easiest approach, it can have some benefits. By calling out the grievances you've experienced, you may be able to bring attention to issues that need to be addressed, which could potentially improve the work environment for your colleagues. Additionally, being direct can show that you're not afraid to stand up for yourself and your needs, which can be a powerful message to your employer.
 However, it's also important to consider the potential risks of being direct. If you decide to leave, it's possible that your employer may not provide a positive reference, especially if you've been openly critical of the workplace. This could impact your future job prospects, so it's important to weigh the potential risks against the potential benefits.
 Ultimately, the decision of how to leave is up to you. If you do decide to be direct, it may be helpful to prepare a clear and professional letter or email that outlines your concerns and reasons for leaving. This can help you maintain a sense of control and professionalism, even in a difficult situation.
 Remember that you don't have to go through this alone. Consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or career counselor for support and guidance as you navigate this decision.
mistral:
I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing a toxic work environment with numerous challenges, including lack of leadership, disrespect, unrelenting deadlines, and micromanaging. It's understandable that you're considering quitting and wondering whether to address your grievances before leaving.

While it's a personal decision, some people find that being direct and expressing their concerns can lead to growth and improvement for both parties. It may help the organization understand the impact of their actions and provide an opportunity for change. However, it's essential to consider the potential consequences, such as the possibility of a strained relationship or being ghosted.

Ultimately, the decision is yours. If you choose to leave silently, you might miss an opportunity to effect change. But if you feel that confrontation would not be productive or safe, it's essential to prioritize your well-being and mental health. Remember, it's okay to prioritize yourself and seek a work environment that supports your growth and well-being.

seeker_post: Workplace made a group chat to talk about another member of staff. Throwaway for obvious reasons.. I'm just looking for some advice as I'm not really sure what to do about this and it's making me feel weird. So, a couple of weeks ago I was on holiday from work and during that time I got a notification that I'd been added to a WhatsApp group from my manager it was named calling another member of staff some bad name and put a stock photo of someone who looked similar to this person. Everyone apart from this person was invited, I never opened the chat I just ignored the chat, the only time I saw the chat was through my notification window at the top of my screen with not only the manager but other people joining in making fun of this person. I opened it once because I thought it was the work chat about rotas etc. As the manager has the same photo but I never read the name of the chat but saw a photo of a drawing someone had done of the person they are talking about and it obviously wasn't a nice one. So anyway, long story short what should I do? Am I just being sensitive because the person they are talking about has always been nice to me and never been an issue or is this workplace bullying? If so, any advice would be helpful. Thanks
gpt4:
It's completely understandable that you're feeling uncomfortable with this situation. Trust your instincts here – what you're describing is not just workplace bullying, but it's also highly unprofessional and inappropriate, especially coming from a manager. It's important to address this issue, not only because it's the right thing to do, but also because it creates a toxic work environment for everyone involved.
 You have a few options on how to proceed. You could approach the person being targeted and let them know what's happening, offering your support. Alternatively, you could speak to your HR department or another manager you trust about the group chat and express your concerns. It's important to document what you've seen, as it could be useful for HR to investigate the matter.
 Remember, by standing up against bullying, you're helping to create a more respectful and professional workplace. It's not about being sensitive; it's about being ethical and supportive of your colleagues. Your courage in addressing this issue can make a significant difference.

 First of all, it's important to acknowledge that you have every right to feel upset and concerned about this. Being added to a group chat that is specifically designed to mock and belittle another member of staff is not okay, and it's not something that you should just ignore or brush off.
 It's possible that your manager and other colleagues may not realize the harm that their words and actions can cause, but that doesn't make it any less hurtful or inappropriate. Bullying in any form is never acceptable, and it's important to speak up and address the situation.
 One option could be to talk to your manager directly and express your concerns. You could say something like, "Hey [manager's name], I noticed that I was added to a group chat that was making fun of [name of person being talked about]. I just wanted to let you know that I don't feel comfortable with this kind of behavior and I think it's important that we treat all colleagues with respect and kindness. Can we talk about why this group chat was created and why I was added to it?"
 If you're not comfortable talking to your manager directly, or if you don't feel like your concerns are being taken seriously, you could also consider talking to HR or someone else in a higher position of authority. They may be able to help mediate the situation and put an end to the bullying behavior.
 Remember that you don't have to deal with this kind of treatment alone, and there are people and resources available to support you. Don't hesitate to reach out if you need any further advice or guidance.

seeker_post:
Coworker keeps nosing into my conversations/business—advice?I am a barista and work full-time with one other colleague who is full-time (everyone else is part-time/students). I’ve started to take on more responsibilities at work as my boss has requested—such as ordering pastries, updating our menu and POS, etc.
Every time I am working on “her” computer (it is a shared computer, not hers), my coworker will come over and ask what I’m doing, what I’m working on, what we’re talking about, etc. when it has nothing to do with her. Normally, I wouldn’t care if someone is curious. But I have to repeat my entire conversation with my boss or with the other employees whenever she comes in, like she HAS to know what we were discussing. Or if I’m working on something like updating our prices, she’s like what are you doing, why, etc. and looks visibly upset that she’s not included. She has responsibilities I don’t and I’ve never cared.
It’s not infuriating or anything but very annoying because a) I don’t think it’s really her problem/business, and b) she’s just very very nosy. She’s 30 years older than me and sometimes acts like I’m a child, so I also don’t like that (her tone/wording can be really dismissive and condescending).
What would you do if you were me? Just let it go? How do I just let it go without it bugging me so much? I don’t want to be rude or confrontational because it’s just me and her sometimes, so I don’t want it to be awkward.
gpt4:
It sounds like you're in a challenging situation with your coworker's behavior feeling intrusive and somewhat dismissive. It's understandable that this dynamic can be frustrating, especially when you're trying to focus on your new responsibilities.
 One approach could be to set gentle but firm boundaries. You might say something like, "I appreciate your interest, but I've got this task under control. If there's anything that involves you or that you need to be updated on, I'll be sure to let you know." This way, you're acknowledging her curiosity while also making it clear that you will share information when it's necessary.
 If her tone is often condescending, it could be helpful to address this directly at a calm moment, expressing that you value a respectful and professional working relationship.
 Remember, it's okay to seek support from your boss if the situation doesn't improve, especially since these tasks were assigned to you. It's important to maintain a comfortable work environment where you can perform your duties effectively.
 Lastly, finding ways to let go of the frustration can be beneficial for your own peace of mind. This might involve deep breathing, taking a short walk, or finding a confidant to vent to outside of work. Balancing professionalism with personal boundaries is key, and you're entitled to a workspace where you can concentrate on your tasks without undue interruption.
llama:
Hey there! I can totally understand how frustrating it can be when someone is consistently nosy and intrusive, especially when it feels like they're not respecting your boundaries. Here are a few suggestions that might help you deal with the situation:
 1. Set clear boundaries: When your coworker starts asking questions, you can politely but firmly tell her that you'd prefer to focus on your work and don't have time to discuss it with her. You can say something like, "I'm in the middle of updating our prices, can we talk about this later?" or "I'm trying to concentrate on my tasks, can you please give me some space?"
 2. Avoid engaging: If she continues to ask questions or try to engage you in conversation, try not to respond or engage. It's okay to politely ignore her or say that you're not interested in talking at that moment.
 3. Focus on your work: Instead of letting her nosiness bug you, try to focus on your work and the tasks at hand. The more you can keep your mind on your work, the less you'll be affected by her behavior.
 4. Talk to your boss: If the behavior continues and you feel like it's affecting your work or creating a hostile work environment, consider talking to your boss about the situation. They may be able to provide guidance on how to handle it or mediate a resolution.
 Remember, you don't have to be rude or confrontational to set boundaries and assert your needs. You can do so in a polite and professional manner, and it's okay to prioritize your own needs and well-being in the workplace.
mistral:
I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling annoyed and disrespected by your coworker's intrusive behavior. It's understandable that you value your privacy and autonomy at work, especially when you're taking on additional responsibilities. Here are some suggestions:

1. Set clear boundaries: You could try setting clear boundaries by politely letting your coworker know that you value your privacy while working and would appreciate being left alone when you're focused on your tasks.
2. Communicate effectively: You could also try explaining to her that her constant interruptions are making it difficult for you to concentrate and complete your work efficiently.
3. Find a solution: Consider discussing with your boss or HR if there's a way to address this issue, such as getting a separate computer for each employee or setting up a schedule for sharing the computer.
4. Practice self-care: Take breaks when you need them, and engage in activities that help you relax and recharge, such as listening to music, reading a book, or taking a walk outside.
5. Seek support: Talk to trusted colleagues or friends about how you're feeling, and seek their advice and encouragement. Remember, you don't have to deal with this situation alone.

Remember, it's important to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being, and to communicate effectively and assertively with your coworker to find a solution that works for both of you.

Nitpicking boss. I have recently transferred from a location where I made basically almost all decisions even with my junior manager level. This new location has a more direct supervisor, and they dictate that I was to remain visible online when working at home, and to let them vet through every single request before moving up to higher management for approval.

I feel so irritated at that from the get go, and that when they vet through the requests, they change literally the most mundane thing about the English. E.g in achieving = to achieve. I argue with them on semantics that I think this should be done first or escalated up.

They chase me on updates that I have already given them, and in the same email thread asks what I am doing about it even thought 2 emails earlier, the answer is there in black and white. I have tried to trash it out with them , having a heart to heart talk and telling them honestly but it doesn't seem to stop. All they say is we need more communication but all the communication is there! I've talked, emailed, short chatted and yet they say i don't update her on stuff.

It's making me pull my hair out because I know my level of English isn't bad, at the very least, everyone else I have asked opinions on understood what I meant immediately, but their reactions and tone are making me doubt myself. I get angry and frustrated and honestly it's no way to work like this.

Previous place used to be high stress workload heavy place but here? My issue is them.

seeker_post: What should I do? My boss denied my first request for time off so she could have time off. She has a kid and I don’t so I had to move my vacation to accommodate so our team could have coverage. Then when I requested time off the next week she wouldn’t approve due to it being more than the original request(2 days vs 4 days) Saying that I couldn’t leave my team hanging like that and that my teammates had come up and told her that me leaving would be hard on the team. I checked with everyone on my team and they said they never said that and that I should take the time off since they all have vacations planned and since I have taken on double the workload. During the meeting with my boss I was scolded saying I take pto more than anyone else on my team. I fact checked this against people’s calendar and I took 3 weeks less than my teammates that she praised for not taking vacation in 2023. I was also told that I should take time off in March when my manager counterpart is taking time off instead of when we have planned our vacation, which seems kind of like an unfair request. FWIW the place I work has unlimited pto. I am worried about retaliation since I voiced that I felt a little uncomfortable by these requests. Also I don’t love where I work and am actively looking for a new job, but it’s kind of a bad job market right now so I am not feeling great. Open to any and all advice.

seeker_post:
Job follow-up. Hey everyone. Wanted to get some input on what you would do in this situation and how to approach a follow up email.
I am unemployed currently and had a job interview on the 18th of this month. I was working in the legal cannabis industry and live in a recreationally legal state so I was still using cannabis. At the interview, I told them I would need a month to pass a drug test for cannabis when they asked if I could pass a drug test right now. Didn’t seem to be an issue, everyone understood that.
I applied on their site for an entry level position probably a month before I actually had this interview (have a friend that works there) and they didn’t realize I had applied/ the job I applied for actually was not available, yet their website never took it off.
So when this all came up, they said they would pass my resume around the departments and see where i could land.
since then I have stopped cannabis cold turkey, will be two weeks on Thursday. I sent one email thanking them for the time they took and the potential opportunity and received a short and sweet email back, saying they will spread that I said thanks and again, pass around my resume.
I want to send another email this week just to get some sort of clarity on if a job is open, could I expect one to come open soon or would they go in a different direction. I just don’t want to come off to snarky but I’m just left in this weird holding phase. So I wanted to see what you all would suggest/ how to word the email?
Thank you.
gpt4:
Hello there,  It's great to hear that you're taking proactive steps in your job search and making the necessary adjustments to align with potential job requirements. It's understandable to feel a bit in limbo after an interview, especially when you're eager to secure employment.
 When crafting your follow-up email, it's important to maintain a professional and courteous tone. You might consider expressing your continued interest in the company and inquire about the status of your application. For example:
 "Dear [Hiring Manager's Name],
  I hope this message finds you well. I wanted to express my continued interest in joining [Company Name] and thank you once again for considering my application. I am very eager to contribute to your team and was wondering if there have been any updates regarding the position or my application status. I understand these processes take time, and I appreciate any information you can provide.
  Thank you for your time and assistance.
  Best regards,
 [Your Name]"
  This approach shows your enthusiasm without being overbearing. It's also a good idea to keep the email concise and to the point. Remember, hiring processes can vary in length, so patience is key. Best of luck, and I hope you hear positive news soon!
llama:
Hey there! I can definitely understand your situation and how frustrating it can be to be left in a holding pattern after an interview. Here's my suggestion for your follow-up email:
 Subject: Follow-up on Job Opportunity and Drug Test
 
 Hi [Hiring Manager's Name],
  I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up on our interview on [Date] and express my continued interest in the [Job Title] position at [Company Name]. I've been waiting to hear back on the status of my application, and I understand that hiring processes can take time.
  I wanted to mention that I have now been two weeks without cannabis, as I mentioned during our interview. I've made sure to abstain from any substances that could potentially interfere with a drug test, and I'm confident that I'm now eligible to move forward. 
 I'd appreciate any clarity you can provide on the current status of the position I applied for, as well as any other potential openings that may be a good fit for my skills and experience. If there's any additional information I can provide to support my application, please don't hesitate to let me know. 
 Thank you for your time and consideration, and I look forward to hearing from you soon. 
 Best regards, 
 [Your Name]
 
 This email should be polite and professional, while also showing that you're eager to move forward and clarify the status of your application. Remember to keep it brief and to the point, and avoid coming across as pushy or demanding. Good luck!

seeker_post:
Doo doo ass coworkers.This is mostly a vent* I’ve been working in healthcare for about a year and a half. It’s new to me, my first ever job, and I’m the youngest in the office (20).
Our office location is all for billing and insurance, so we aren’t people facing. We show up in sweats and joggers, it’s a super lax office bc we’re a smaller billing company.
There are however some billers at another office location. Their location is client facing- they have a very nice, new office in the heart of a rapidly growing city outside of Dallas. Meanwhile, we have a little, older office- bc we aren’t client facing! Unfortunately being the billing company, we’re often forgotten and in the background.
Anyways, this one particular gal at the nicer office who does insurance, likes to give all her work to me. Dumps it on me. My manager gives her the approval to do so. No one is even sure what her role is, and today her excuse for dumping ALL her work on me is that she’s backing someone else up. She won’t tell us who. My manager complains about is as do i, that she’s lazy and doesn’t want to do her own work, but then my manager allows it to happen.
I’m insanely frustrated. I’m happy to help her and do her work, but here’s some past instances when this has happened:
she dumps her work on me, then asks me to not do it anymore because I’m taking “all of her daily tasks”
